blocks.text: Graphic construction. With any convenient radius OD describe an arc of a circle. Draw OA, OB and OE, making the angle DOA = 74°; AOB = 76°; AOC = 78°; and DBC at right angles to OB, intersecting at the point C. Note that C lies outside the triangle AOB.

Then E and C being fixed, construct the arc of a circle EH perpendicular to OB at the point E and join EH. Then the arc RE is the value of the required angle A, and is found to be in the neighbourhood of 78°. If the arc had fallen the other side of OA, the angle E would have been measured.

The actual spherical triangle ABC is formed by the circular arc AC and the perpendicular radial arc AE. It is thus a subtended angle of 41° at the center. The side BC is marked 76° and its actual length of b, does not represent its true distance in this manner either.

Let the circular sector OAB be rotated about OA as axis, and the resultant surfaces OA  
BC be formed into a solid of revolution. This creates a solid cone of height OB and slant height OAB, and thus the relation OAB is produced.
The line from the center O to point A is OA; and the line from the center O to point B is OB. The solid thus formed has a volume clearly illustrated by the dimensional formula shown below.

blocks.description: Volume of the cone formed by rotating the sector OAB around OA.
